'''Ross Andrew Parker''' (17 August 1984 – 21 September 2001), from [[Peterborough]], England, was a 17-year-old White English male murdered in an unprovoked [[racially motivated crime]]. He bled to death after being stabbed, beaten with a hammer, and repeatedly kicked by a gang of [[United Kingdom|British]] Pakistani youths.<ref name=autogenerated6 /><ref name=autogenerated8> {{cite news | last = Reville | first = Alan | date = 22 September 2011 | title = Murdered Ross Parker remembered 10 years on | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/local/murdered_ross_parker_remembered_10_years_on_1_3077380 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | accessdate= 27 December 2011}}</ref><ref name =Times>{{Cite news|title=Muslims offer reward to find Asian gang behind white youth's death|newspaper=The Times|location=London|publisher=News UK|date=24 September 2001|page=3|first=Dominic|last=Kennedy}}</ref> The incident occurred in [[Millfield, Peterborough]], ten days after the [[September 11 attacks]].<ref name="Guardian1"> {{cite news | last = Morris | first = Steven | date = 20 December 2002 | title = Three get life in jail for racist killing | url = https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2002/dec/20/race.world | newspaper = The Guardian | location = London | publisher = Guardian Media Group | accessdate=28 July 2011}}{{cite news | last = Stevens | first = John | date = 15 January 2014 | title = Peterborough child sex gang found guilty of rapes against five girls | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2540061/Child-sex-gang-guilty-series-rapes-against-five-vulnerable-girls-including-one-just-12-years-old.html | newspaper = Daily Mail | location = London | publisher = DMG Media | accessdate= 10 July 2014}}</ref>
In December 2002, Shaied Nazir, Ahmed Ali Awan, and Sarfraz Ali were all, unanimously, found guilty of Parker's murder and sentenced to [[life imprisonment]], each receiving minimum terms ranging from 16 to 18 years. A fourth defendant, Zairaff Mahrad, was cleared of murder and [[manslaughter]].<ref name="news.bbc.co.uk"> {{cite news | author =<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Three guilty of teenager's murder | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/2590539.stm | work = BBC News | location = London | publisher = BBC | date = 19 December 2002 | accessdate= 28 July 2011 }}</ref><ref name="dailymail.co.uk">{{cite news | last = Price | first = Richard | date = 8 November 2002 | title = Teenager 'killed by vicious knife gang' | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-146572/Teenager-killed-vicious-knife-gang.html | newspaper = Daily Mail | location = London | publisher = Associated Newspapers | accessdate=28 July 2011}}</ref>
A memorial plaque for Parker is located in the [[Netherton, Peterborough|Netherton]] area of Peterborough where a [[Association football|football]] match is played each year in his memory.
==Background== Ross Parker was born in Peterborough in 1984 to Davinia and Tony Parker. His mother worked as a waitress and his father ran a car bodywork repair business; he was one of two children.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ross Parker Trial: 'What they did was unforgivable'|url=http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment_2_17112/ross_parker_trial_what_they_did_was_unforgivable_1_106337|newspaper=Peterborough Evening Telegraph|location=Peterborough|publisher=Johnston Press|date=20 December 2002|accessdate=28 July 2011}}</ref> Parker was an avid [[Association football|football player]] and, having completed a [[GNVQ]] in [[business studies]] at [[Jack Hunt School]], hoped to join the police force when he was 18. He was nicknamed [[Pint|"Half-Pint]]" owing to his 5-foot, 5-inch height and had twice broken his leg previously. Parker lived in the [[Westwood, Peterborough|Westwood]] area of the city and worked [[part-time]] as bar support at The Solstice, a local [[public house]] where he had met his girlfriend, Nicola Toms.<ref name=PeterboroughET4>{{cite news|title=Workmates and friends stunned by tragic death|url=http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment_2_17112/workmates_and_friends_stunned_by_tragic_death_1_107870|newspaper=Peterborough Evening Telegraph|location=Peterborough, UK|publisher=Johnston Press|date=22 September 2001|accessdate=28 July 2011}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated5>{{Cite news|title=Murder: Family tells of months of torment after death of much-loved son|url=http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment/murder_family_tells_of_months_of_torment_after_death_of_much_loved_son_1_104950|newspaper=Peterborough Evening Telegraph|location=Peterborough, UK|publisher=Johnston Press|date=25 January 2002|accessdate= 27 December 2011}}</ref><ref name="BBC News 1">{{cite news|title=Twelve held over teenager's death|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/1557154.stm|work=BBC News|location=London, UK|publisher=BBC|date=23 September 2001|accessdate=29 July 2011}}</ref><ref name=PeterboroughET6/>
==Murder== Parker was murdered shortly after 1:15 a.m. on Friday 21 September 2001 while walking with his girlfriend.<ref name=PeterboroughET6> {{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Murder: Terror as Ross's killers pounced | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment_2_17112/murder_terror_as_ross_s_killers_pounced_1_104974 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 6 January 2003 | accessdate= 29 July 2011}}</ref> The attack took place on a [[cycle path]] alongside Bourges Boulevard in [[Millfield, Peterborough]], near to Russell Street.<ref name=PeterboroughET3> {{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Killing: 'Life without Ross is hard. It never goes away' | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment_2_17112/killing_life_without_ross_is_hard_it_never_goes_away_1_104375 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 20 September 2002 | accessdate=29 July 2011}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated10> {{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Three in court on Ross murder charge | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment/three_in_court_on_ross_murder_charge_1_107264 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 26 September 2001 | accessdate=27 December 2011}}</ref> Racial tensions in the area were high as the [[September 11 attacks]] had only occurred ten days earlier.<ref name="Guardian1"/>
Having finished work early, Parker and Toms were walking to visit her friend's house<ref name=PeterboroughET6/> when they were confronted by a gang of around ten Pakistani youths, some of whom were wearing [[Balaclava (clothing)|balaclavas]];<ref name =Times/><ref name=autogenerated8 /><ref name=autogenerated2> {{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Youth murdered in gang attack | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment/youth_murdered_in_gang_attack_1_107927 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 21 September 2001 | accessdate=27 December 2011}}</ref><ref name=peterboroughtoday.co.uk/> the 2002 trial judge concluded that they had planned to find "a white male to attack simply because he was white" in the context of "hostility on the part of some of the younger white residents of the city against the Asian community".<ref name=autogenerated6 /> They warned Parker he had "better start running", but then blocked his path and quickly sprayed him in the face with [[CS gas]].<ref name=autogenerated9> {{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Court: 'I heard him cry out two or three times – then there was no sound at all' | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment/court_i_heard_him_cry_out_two_or_three_times_then_there_was_no_sound_at_all_1_56824 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 8 November 2002 | accessdate=27 December 2011}}</ref> He was punched in the stomach then stabbed three times from behind through the throat and chest with a foot-long [[hunting knife]].<ref name=autogenerated6> {{Cite web | url = http://www.hmcourts-service.gov.uk/cms/144_13295.htm | title = R. v. Ahmed Ali Awan, [2008] EWHC 119 (QB) | publisher = Her Majesty's Court Service | date = 30 January 2008 | accessdate= 27 December 2011 | archiveurl = http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20110218200720/http://www.hmcourts-service.gov.uk/cms/144_13295.htm | archivedate = 18 February 2011 | deadurl = yes}}</ref> The knife penetrated completely through his body on two occasions and as he was lying on the ground he was repeatedly kicked and struck with a [[panel beater]]'s hammer.<ref name=peterboroughtoday.co.uk> {{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Ross killers fail in bid to have sentences cut | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment_2_17112/ross_killers_fail_in_bid_to_have_sentences_cut_1_93471 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 30 January 2008 | accessdate=29 July 2011}}</ref>
Toms ran to a nearby [[petrol station]] for help and a man there gave her his mobile phone to call the police. While making the call, she twice heard Parker cry out in pain. By chance she spotted a passing police car. She entered the car and guided the officer to the scene of the assault.<ref name=PeterboroughET6/> Although Toms had only been away for a few minutes, by the time she returned Parker had already [[Exsanguination|bled to death]] and the gang had disappeared.<ref name=autogenerated2 /><ref name=PeterboroughET2> {{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Funeral: Tributes paid to 'beacon of light' | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment/funeral_tributes_paid_to_beacon_of_light_1_103256 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 24 October 2001 | accessdate=27 December 2011}}</ref>
After the murder, four of the gang returned to a garage which they used as their headquarters. Ahmed Ali Awan, brandishing the bloodied knife, exclaimed "cherish the blood".<ref name="Guardian1"/><ref name="dailymail.co.uk"/><ref name=autogenerated2 /> The police informed Parker's family of his death at 4:30 am; his body remained at the scene during the day while an investigation was conducted.<ref name=autogenerated5/><ref name=autogenerated2 /> A [[post-mortem]] revealed Parker had died as a result of stab wounds inflicted by a bladed instrument.<ref> {{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Police and Asian community in show of unity after killing | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment/police_and_asian_community_in_show_of_unity_after_killing_1_105467 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 22 September 2001 | accessdate=27 December 2011}}</ref>
==Arrests and charges== Parker's murder sparked what became one of the biggest police inquiries in the history of Peterborough.<ref name=peterboroughtoday2> {{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Ross Parker Trial: Cold-blooded, racist murder | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment_2_17112/ross_parker_trial_cold_blooded_racist_murder_1_106338 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 20 December 2002 |accessdate=29 July 2011}}</ref> During the weekend following the attack, twelve suspects of Pakistani descent were arrested on suspicion of murder. Members of the local community posted a £1,000 reward for information leading to the arrest of the killers,<ref name="BBC News 1"/><ref> {{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Police quiz seven over fatal stabbing of a 'happy-go lucky' teenager | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment_2_17112/police_quiz_seven_over_fatal_stabbing_of_a_happy_go_lucky_teenager_1_105505 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 24 September 2001 | accessdate= 29 July 2011}}</ref> later increasing to £1,500.<ref> {{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Murder – 'The whole of the community mourns' | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment_2_17112/murder_the_whole_of_the_community_mourns_1_104926 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 2 October 2001 | accessdate= 29 July 2011}}</ref> A number of those arrested were recorded chanting "[[Taliban]], [[Osama bin Laden]]" in their cells<ref name=PeterboroughET9> {{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Court: Ross was killed 'by a hunting party' | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment_2_17112/court_ross_was_killed_by_a_hunting_party_1_56919 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 16 December 2002 | accessdate= 29 July 2011}}</ref> and while being transported in the police van, which they also vandalised.<ref name=PeterboroughET5> {{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Court: 'It was Ali Awan's knife ... he was a leader ... he liked to be big' | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment_2_17112/court_it_was_ali_awan_s_knife_he_was_a_leader_he_liked_to_be_big_1_56826 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 11 November 2002 | accessdate=29 July 2011}}</ref> [[Chief inspector|Detective Chief Inspector]] Dick Harrison, who was overseeing the case, praised the city's Muslim community for their involvement in capturing the murderers.<ref name=autogenerated8 />
On 26 September 2001, Sarfraz Ali, Ahmed Ali Awan and Shaied Nazir appeared in court charged with Parker's murder.<ref name=autogenerated10 /> Zairaff Mahrad was charged the following day.<ref name=PeterboroughET2 /><ref name=PeterboroughET1 /> However, by March 2002 all four defendants had been controversially released on [[police bail]]. Parker's sister, Leanne, stated "we can't begin to comprehend why they've been allowed out of prison at this stage". Parker's family were so concerned about the decision that they wrote a letter of complaint to the Home Secretary, [[David Blunkett]]. The [[Home Office]] refused to comment on the case and the men remained free on bail.<ref> {{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Courts: Parents question bail in murder case | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment_2_17112/courts_parents_question_bail_in_murder_case_1_101270 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 13 May 2002 | accessdate= 29 July 2011}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated11> {{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Court: Ross Parker trial is hit by delay | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment/court_ross_parker_trial_is_hit_by_delay_1_56918 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 6 November 2002 | accessdate= 3 January 2012}}</ref>
==Trial== On 7 November 2002, Awan, Nazir, Ali and Mahrad all of Millfield, Peterborough, stood trial for Parker's murder at [[Northampton Crown Court]], pleading not guilty.<ref name=peterboroughtoday2/><ref name=autogenerated11 />
Awan, 22, ran a recruitment company and had previously attended the city's [[Deacon's School]]. He was an unofficial [[Informant|police informer]] and the court was told he thought of himself as a gangster and had a "fantasy for knives".<ref> {{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Court: Haul of knives found during search of defendant's home, jury is told | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment/court_haul_of_knives_found_during_search_of_defendant_s_home_jury_is_told_1_56884 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 20 November 2002 | accessdate= 3 January 2012}}</ref><ref> {{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Court: 'Awan liked to think he was a gangster he's got a fantasy about knives' | url =http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment/court_awan_liked_to_think_he_was_a_gangster_he_s_got_a_fantasy_about_knives_1_56817 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 13 November 2002 | accessdate= 3 January 2012}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated7>{{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Ross Trial: The guilty men | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment/ross_trial_the_guilty_men_1_106340 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 19 December 2002 | accessdate= 3 January 2012}}</ref> Nazir, 22, was close friends with Awan. He was married in [[Kashmir]] the month prior to the murder and had a son. He was educated at [[The Voyager School|Bretton Woods School]], had worked in a factory and later in a [[takeaway|takeaway restaurant]] with Mahrad, whom he had known since childhood.<ref>{{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Court: Nazir: 'I lied to police over killing to protect my friends' | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment/court_nazir_i_lied_to_police_over_killing_to_protect_my_friends_1_56903 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 28 November 2002 | accessdate= 3 January 2012}}</ref> Ali, 25, had also attended Bretton Woods School and was also married, though his wife left him during the trial.<ref name=autogenerated12>{{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Court: Chilling warning to accused after being told to deliver bloodied clothes | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment/court_chilling_warning_to_accused_after_being_told_to_deliver_bloodied_clothes_1_56847 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 19 November 2002 | accessdate= 3 January 2012}}</ref><ref name="Slept"> {{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Court: 'I slept as Ross was murdered', claim | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment/court_i_slept_as_ross_was_murdered_claim_1_56825 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 6 December 2002 | accessdate= 3 January 2012}}</ref> He was given a [[Reference#Law|reference]] at the trial by the [[Deputy Mayor]] of Peterborough, Raja Akhtar.<ref name=Guardian1/> and [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] councillor Mohammed Choudhary, with Akhtar stating he had "known him to be caring and responsible".<ref>{{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Court: Deputy mayor's defence for Ali | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment_2_17112/court_deputy_mayor_s_defence_for_ali_1_56863 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 9 December 2002 | accessdate= 29 July 2011}}</ref> Mahrad, 21, owned a takeaway restaurant business in [[King's Lynn]].<ref name=autogenerated12 />
During the six-week trial, transcripts of covert police recordings of the suspects discussing the attack were submitted as evidence. These conversations took place in police vehicles when the suspects were arrested and were translated from [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]]. Nazir was heard describing Parker's death as a "bloodbath", and how the third blow from the knife had split the whole of his neck open. Awan and Nazir were both heard discussing the statements they had given to police and the plan they had "made up".<ref>{{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Court: Jury hears accused describe killing as 'a bloodbath' on secret tapes | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment_2_17112/court_jury_hears_accused_describe_killing_as_a_bloodbath_on_secret_tapes_1_56888 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 26 November 2002 | accessdate= 29 July 2011}}</ref> The court was also told of an exchange between Awan and an inmate at [[Bedford Prison]], in which Awan described the killing of Parker in lurid detail.<ref name=autogenerated7 /> Contents of a letter written by Mahrad were also presented in which he stated he would "pray to [[Allah]] for forgiveness".<ref>{{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Court: Court hears of 'mission to kill' | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment/court_court_hears_of_mission_to_kill_1_56855 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date =5 December 2002 | accessdate= 3 January 2012}}</ref>
The jury heard how the murder weapons had been found in a shed at Nazir's house along with two bags of bloodied clothes. [[DNA]] and fingerprints belonging to Nazir was found on the hunting knife and Parker's blood was found on both the hammer and knife. His blood was also found on the clothes of two of the accused, along with Nazir and Mahrad's DNA<ref name=PeterboroughET5/><ref name=autogenerated4>{{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Court: Expert tells jury of DNA linking Nazir to knife used in killing of Ross | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment_2_17112/court_expert_tells_jury_of_dna_linking_nazir_to_knife_used_in_killing_of_ross_1_56875 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 21 November 2002 | accessdate= 29 July 2011}}</ref><ref name=PeterboroughET11>{{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Court: Gang's vow not to hurt women | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/local/court-gang-s-vow-not-to-hurt-women-1-56879 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 12 December 2002 | accessdate= 5 June 2014}}</ref> and a [[pathologist]] told how marks on Parker's body matched the hammer found in Nazir's shed.<ref>{{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Court: Mother breaks down as expert tells jury terrible details of Ross's death | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment/court_mother_breaks_down_as_expert_tells_jury_terrible_details_of_ross_s_death_1_56897 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 25 November 2002 | accessdate= 3 January 2012}}</ref> Three balaclavas were also recovered from the property, again containing traces of Parker's blood,<ref>{{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Court: Mum's tears as jury hears how Ross was found lying in a pool of blood | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment_2_17112/court_mum_s_tears_as_jury_hears_how_ross_was_found_lying_in_a_pool_of_blood_1_56901 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 22 November 2002 | accessdate= 29 July 2011}}</ref> Nazir's younger brother Wyed told the court he had seen his brother cleaning the murder weapon on the night of the killing and witnessed all four defendants with blood on their clothing.<ref name=autogenerated4 /><ref>{{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title= Brother saw bloody knife, court told | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/2418603.stm | work = BBC News | location = London | publisher = BBC | date = 7 November 2002 | accessdate=3 January 2012}}</ref> Further witnesses reported Nazir admitting to beating someone up, Mahrad admitting to kicking Parker and Awan recalling stabbing him. A witness also saw all four defendants kicking Parker.<ref>{{Cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Courts: Stabbed, beaten, kicked to death | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/local/courts-stabbed-beaten-kicked-to-death-1-101287 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 7 November 2002 | accessdate= 6 November 2013}}</ref>
In court Nazir admitted to seeing the victim lying on the ground and attempting to spray him with CS gas and kicking him. He also acknowledged washing the murder weapon and stated Ali had hit Parker with the hammer and Awan used the knife.<ref>{{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Murder accused blames friend | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/2525793.stm | work = BBC News | location = London | publisher = BBC | date = 28 November 2002 | accessdate= 3 January 2012}}</ref> Nazir also alleged prosecution witnesses Zaheer Abbas and Adeel Rehman had been involved in the attack too.<ref name=PeterboroughET8>{{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Court: Nazir tells court he kicked Ross during attack but did not know about stabbing | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/local/court-nazir-tells-court-he-kicked-ross-during-attack-but-did-not-know-about-stabbing-1-56902 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 29 November 2002 | accessdate= 5 June 2014}}</ref> Mahrad had also admitted to being present at the murder scene, and claimed that the blood stains found on his trousers occurred as a result of his accidentally falling across Parker. Ali, defended by Mohammed Latif, denied being at the scene and claimed to have been asleep at the time of the murder, although a recording from a police van indicated this was a "story" that he had encouraged the others to "stick to".<ref name=autogenerated9/><ref name=Slept/> Awan also denied being present and claimed he had been at home playing on his [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]] with Shokat Awan, his brother.<ref name=PeterboroughET14>{{cite news | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Court: Awan told 'pack of lies' to court | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/local/court-awan-told-pack-of-lies-to-court-1-56838 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 11 December 2002 | accessdate= 3 July 2014}}</ref> Nigel Rumfitt QC, defending Awan, summarised the crime by stating: "These people were not taking the night air. Every member of the group knew what was going on. These weapons had been selected before they set off. The knife was far too big to be hidden from the others. There is no doubt there was a hunting party looking for a victim."<ref name=PeterboroughET9/>
On 19 December 2002, Nazir, Awan and Ali were all found guilty of murder in [[Unanimous#Juries|unanimous verdicts]].<ref name="news.bbc.co.uk"/><ref name=peterboroughtoday2/> The judge, [[Edwin Jowitt|Sir Edwin Jowitt]], summarised the murder during sentencing:
{{Quote|You put your heads together with the purpose of arming yourselves and of attacking an innocent man you might find by chance simply because he was of a different race to yourselves. A racist killing must be one of the gravest kinds of killing.}}
The judge concluded that Awan had wielded the knife, was the ringleader of the group and had intended to kill.<ref name=autogenerated2 /> The three received [[life sentences]], with Awan to serve a minimum of 18 years and the others at least 16. Mahrad was cleared of murder and [[manslaughter]].<ref name="news.bbc.co.uk"/>
==Post-trial and appeals== After the trial it was revealed that Nazir had previously been [[police caution|cautioned]] for using threatening behaviour in 1999 and fined for resisting arrest.<ref name=autogenerated7 /> The two Labour politicians, Akhtar and Choudhary, who provided Ali's references were later jailed themselves for forgery in relation to [[Electoral fraud|vote rigging]].<ref>{{cite news | author =<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Three jailed over rigged election | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/cambridgeshire/7335364.stm | work = BBC News | location = London | publisher = BBC | date= 7 April 2008 | accessdate=3 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | author =<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Special Report: How police investigated vote rigging offences | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment/special_report_how_police_investigated_vote_rigging_offences_1_113171 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 23 July 2008 | accessdate= 3 January 2012}}</ref>
Awan and Nazir [[appealed]] against their jail terms in January 2008 but the original sentences were upheld. Judge [[Nigel Davis|Justice Davis]] said he had taken into account "moving" statements from Parker's family.<ref name=HMCourts2> {{Cite web | url = http://www.hmcourts-service.gov.uk/cms/144_13296.htm | title = R. v. Shaied Nazir, [2008] EWHC 42 (QB) | publisher = Her Majesty's Court Service | date = 30 January 2008 | accessdate= 27 December 2011 | archiveurl = http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20110218200720/http://www.hmcourts-service.gov.uk/cms/144_13296.htm | archivedate = 18 February 2011 | deadurl = yes}}</ref> Ali appealed his sentence in July 2009 and also had his sentence upheld.<ref name=HMCourts3> {{cite web | url = http://www.hmcourts-service.gov.uk/cms/144_14958.htm | title= R. v. Sarfraz Ali, [2009] EWHC 1551 (QB) | publisher = Her Majesty's Court Service | date = 7 July 2009 | accessdate=27 December 2011 | archiveurl = http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20110218200720/http://www.hmcourts-service.gov.uk/cms/144_14958.htm | archivedate = 4 February 2011 | deadurl = yes}}</ref> After the first two appeals Parker's father suggested that the killers of his son should never be freed.<ref name="peterboroughtoday.co.uk"/> As noted by Justice Davis, had the crime occurred post-2005, then it is likely that significantly higher minimum terms would have been imposed on the perpetrators owing to [[Murder in English law#Criminal Justice Act 2003|reforms in the Criminal Justice Act 2003]].<ref name=HMCourts2/> These reforms recommend a minimum term of 30 years for racially aggravated murder.<ref name="cps_guide">{{cite web | url = http://www.cps.gov.uk/legal/s_to_u/sentencing_manual/murder/ | title = CPS sentencing manual: Murder: Sentencing Legislation and Guidelines | date = 20 March 2013 | publisher = The Crown Prosecution Service | accessdate=1 July 2014}}</ref>
==Reporting== The BBC Editorial Standards Committee in 2007 found that "there was no evidence to suggest that the BBC had shown a specific and systemic bias in favour of cases where the victim had been black or Asian", but accepted it had "underplayed its coverage of the Ross Parker case" and repeated the failings in its coverage of the [[Murder of Kriss Donald]].<ref name=BBCcomplaint>{{cite web|url=http://downloads.bbc.co.uk/bbctrust/assets/files/pdf/appeals/esc_bulletins/30oct07.pdf|title=Editorial Standards Findings: Appeals to the Trust and other editorial standards matters considered by the Editorial Standards Committee|publisher=The BBC Trust|date=30 October 2007|accessdate=2 May 2014|page=3}}</ref>
[[Yasmin Alibhai-Brown]]<ref name="Evening Standard">{{cite news|last=Alibhai Brown|first=Yasmin|title=When the victim is white, does anyone care?|url=https://www.questia.com/read/1G1-153368757/when-the-victim-is-white-does-anyone-care|newspaper=London Evening Standard|location=London, UK|publisher=Associated Newspapers Ltd.|date=26 October 2006|accessdate=30 May 2014|subscription=yes}}</ref> and [[Kelvin MacKenzie]] expressed similar sentiments. MacKenzie criticised newspapers including his own employer, ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]''. He stated, "if you believe you're a victim of an [[ethnic minority]] and you're white there is nowhere to go. Editors are so liberal that they are scared to be seen that they're moving to the [[Right-wing politics|right]] of their paper". Parker's mother, Davinia, expressed similar concerns that white victims of race crime are ignored. She said "because we are white, English, we didn't get the coverage", adding ""it's as if we don't count".<ref name="Newsnight">{{cite episode|title=Newsnight|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/newsnight/6130110.stm|series=Newsnight|serieslink=Newsnight|credits=Presenters:[[Gavin Esler]], [[Martha Kearney]] , Discussion Panel: [[Mark Easton]], [[Kelvin MacKenzie]], [[Lee Jasper]] Interviewee: Davinia Parker|network=[[BBC]]|station=[[BBC Two]]|location=London, UK|airdate=8 October 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Easton|first=Mark|title=Redefining racist crime|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/player/nol/newsid_6130000/newsid_6130300/6130328.stm?bw=bb&mp=wm&news=1|work=BBC News|location=London, UK|publisher= BBC|date=8 November 2006|accessdate=30 July 2011}}</ref>
In 2006, a ''[[The Sunday Times|Sunday Times]]'' investigation by Brendan Montague examined British newspaper archives for coverage of racist crimes, finding "an almost total [[boycott]] of stories involving the white victims of attacks" whereas "cases involving black and minority ethnic victims are widely reported".<ref name="Sunday Times">{{Cite news|last=Montague|first=Brendan|title=The hidden white victims of racism|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article633759.ece|newspaper=The Sunday Times|location=London, UK|publisher=News UK|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629121149/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article633759.ece?token=null&offset=12&page=2|archivedate=29 June 2011|date=12 November 2006|accessdate=29 July 2011|subscription=yes}}</ref>
Others have noted that the lack of coverage is not simply a media issue. [[Peter Fahy]], the spokesman on race issues for the [[Association of Chief Police Officers]] said: "A lot of police officers and other professionals feel almost the best thing to do is to try and avoid [discussing such attacks] for fear of being criticised. This is not healthy". Montague suggests the lack of police appeals in cases involving white victims may be a cause of the lack of media coverage.<ref name="Sunday Times"/> Evidence of this was seen in the Parker case, with the police initially appearing keen to dismiss the possible racist aspect of the murder, stating "there was no reason to believe that the attack was racially motivated".<ref name="bbc5"> {{cite news | title = Teenager beaten to death | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/1555927.stm | work = BBC News | location = London | publisher = BBC | date = 21 September 2001 | accessdate= 25 April 2014 }}</ref>
American [[Townhall]] commentator Larry Provost focused on the religion of the attackers as the key factor in the murder. Writing in August 2014, he suggested the perpetrators were [[Islamists]] who had been "motivated by religion".<ref name="TownHall">{{cite news|author=Larry Provost|title=Islamic Terror in the UK|url=http://townhall.com/columnists/larryprovost/2014/08/15/islamic-terror-in-the-uk-n1878301/page/full|work=TownHall.com|location=Nashville|publisher=Salem Web Network|date=15 August 2014|accessdate=29 August 2014}}</ref>
The newspaper which covered Parker's murder more extensively faced criticism. The [[Government Office for the East of England]] produced a report by Dr Roger Green examining race relations in Peterborough. The document suggested that the ''[[Peterborough Evening Telegraph]]'' had a history of insensitivity, and coverage of the case was "possibly adding to any climate of racial and communal unrest". The criticism of the paper was rejected by a senior police officer and an Asian community leader, both of whom praised its handling of the case.<ref>{{cite news|title=Race: Report critical of '50s attitude' to race issues|url=http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment/race_report_critical_of_50s_attitude_to_race_issues_1_105934|newspaper=Peterborough Evening Telegraph|location=Peterborough|publisher=Johnston Press|date=5 April 2002|accessdate=3 January 2012}}</ref>
The leader of [[Peterborough City Council]] called the report by Dr Green unfair.<ref>{{cite news|title=Racism: City leaders' anger at 'biased' report|url=http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/local/racism-city-leaders-anger-at-biased-report-1-105940|newspaper=Peterborough Evening Telegraph|location=Peterborough|publisher=Johnston Press|date=4 April 2002|accessdate=29 April 2014}}</ref>
==Impact== Parker's murder led to increased racial tensions in Peterborough. At his former school, three Asian pupils were suspended for an attack on an Afro-Caribbean pupil; a relative of the victim then attacked an Asian teacher.<ref>{{cite news | author =<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Attack – School's plea for calm | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment/attack_school_s_plea_for_calm_1_55679 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date = 4 October 2001 | accessdate= 3 January 2012}}</ref> A number of taxi firms stopped work early in the days after the attack in fear of reprisals.<ref>{{cite news | author =<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Meeting – Taxi drivers to go back on road | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment/meeting_taxi_drivers_to_go_back_on_road_1_104739 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date= 3 October 2001 | accessdate= 3 January 2012}}</ref> In November 2001 Home Secretary David Blunkett banned all marches in Peterborough for three months as it was feared violence would be caused by the [[Anti-Nazi League]] and [[National Front (UK)|National Front]] who both sought to hold protests on the same day.<ref>{{cite news | author =<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | title = Parade: Blunkett pulls the plug on NF march | url = http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment/demonstrations_keep_them_out_1_101993 | newspaper = Peterborough Evening Telegraph | location = Peterborough | publisher = Johnston Press | date= 15 November 2001 | accessdate= 3 January 2012}}</ref>
Parker's death also had a major impact on his family. His mother, Davinia, was unable to work for three months after Parker's funeral and came close to attempting suicide on a number of occasions. Parker's room was left largely untouched for three years after the incident because his parents were reluctant to tidy it. They described the room as a place they "feel close to Ross".<ref name=autogenerated5/><ref name=PeterboroughET3 /><ref name=PeterboroughET1/>
==Legacy== [[File:Peterborough Crematorium - geograph.org.uk - 521709.jpg|thumb|Peterborough Crematorium, location of Parker's funeral and memorial]] As a result of the murder of Parker, local authorities set up a unity scheme, whereby gang members from different communities were trained as youth workers to ease racial tensions and reduce violence.<ref>{{cite news|last=Brown|first=Jonathan|title=How two racists faced each other in court, then shunned prejudice to become friends|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/this-britain/how-two-racists-faced-each-other-in-court-then-shunned-prejudice-to-become-friends-415258.html|newspaper=The Independent|location=London, UK|publisher=Independent Print Limited|date=9 September 2006|accessdate=29 July 2011}}</ref> However, problems still persisted, with racist [[graffiti]] painted by "yobs" and "thugs" near the murder scene two years after the incident reading "[[no go area]] for whites", "[[Paki (slur)|Paki]] powa" and "death to whites".<ref>{{cite news|title=Racism: Community condemns graffiti|url=http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment_2_17112/racism_community_condemns_graffiti_1_144031|newspaper=Peterborough Evening Telegraph|location=Peterborough, UK|publisher=Johnston Press|date=11 September 2003|accessdate= 29 July 2011}}</ref>
[[Mark Easton]] cited the Parker case as demonstrating how society has been forced to redefine racism and discard the erroneous definition of "prejudice plus power"—a definition which, in Easton's view, tended to only allow [[ethnic minorities]] to be victims and whites to be perpetrators. He also considered that "Describing an incident as racist may say as much about a victim's mindset as the offender. How else can one explain the British Crime Survey finding that 3,100 car thefts from Asians were deemed to be racially motivated?"<ref name="BBC News 2">{{cite news|last=Easton|first=Mark|title=Racism and race crime redefined|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/6128466.stm|work=BBC News|location=London, UK|publisher=BBC|date=8 November 2006|accessdate=29 July 2011}}</ref> Yasmin Alibhai-Brown condemned the [[double standards]] of [[racial equality]] campaigners in relation to the case, suggesting [[Black British|black]] activists should "march and remember victims like Ross Parker ... our values are worthless unless all victims of these senseless deaths matter equally". She went on to write that "to treat some victims as more worthy of condemnation than others is unforgivable and a betrayal of [[anti-racism]] itself".<ref name="Evening Standard"/><ref name=Independent1>{{cite news|last=Alibhai-Brown|first=Yasmin|title=Brown/Black racism is every bit as bad as white racism|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/opinion/commentators/yasmin-alibhai-brown/black-racism-is-every-bit-as-bad-as-white-racism-596435.html|newspaper=The Independent|location=London, UK|publisher=Independent Print Limited|date=3 February 2003|accessdate=28 July 2011}}</ref>
==Tributes== Parker's funeral took place at Peterborough [[Crematory|Crematorium]] in [[Marholm]] on 23 October 2001 and more than 400 mourners attended. His "number 14" Netherton United [[Kit (association football)|football shirt]] was draped over his coffin and his teammates formed a [[guard of honour]] dressed in the same strip (kit). [[The Reverend]] Geoffrey Keating described Parker as "a beacon of light who inspired so many people" and "an extremely popular young man".<ref name=PeterboroughET2/><ref>{{cite news|title=Murdered — Tributes to Ross on eve of funeral|url=http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment_2_17112/murdered_tributes_to_ross_on_eve_of_funeral_1_104976|newspaper=Peterborough Evening Telegraph|location=Peterborough, UK|publisher=Johnston Press|date=22 October 2001|accessdate=29 July 2011}}</ref>
The murder received little attention from politicians, although in 2003 [[Peterborough (UK Parliament constituency)|Peterborough]] [[Member of Parliament]] [[Helen Clark (British politician)|Helen Clark]] made a statement in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] sending condolences to Parker's family, paying tribute to the Peterborough community and in particular Parker's former school. She described Parker's killers only as "men older than him" and her tributes were echoed by [[John Denham (politician)|John Denham]].<ref>{{cite hansard|house=House of Commons|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200203/cmhansrd/vo030123/halltext/30123h01.htm|date=23 January 2003|column=160WH|accessdate=3 January 2012|title=Parliament UK}}</ref>
A [[Commemorative plaque|plaque]] was installed in [[Netherton, Peterborough|Netherton]] in Peterborough as a memorial to Parker, and a further memorial is located at Peterborough Crematorium.<ref name=autogenerated8/> His former football team mates and friends also play a match every May in his memory and formed a team called "Ross' Rangers".<ref name=PeterboroughET1>{{cite news|last=Franklin|first=Neil|title=In Focus: Three years on the sense of loss is still so real|url=http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/environment_2_17112/in_focus_three_years_on_the_sense_of_loss_is_still_so_real_1_151261|newspaper=Peterborough Evening Telegraph|location=Peterborough, UK|publisher=Johnston Press|date=22 September 2004|accessdate=29 July 2011}}</ref>
A rose bush was also planted at the Parker family home in remembrance.<ref name=PeterboroughET3 />
==See also== *[[Murder of Richard Everitt]] – a similar case from 1994 in [[Somers Town, London]] *[[Murder of Kriss Donald]] – a similar case from 2004 that occurred in [[Glasgow]]

The '''Nordic Language Convention''' is a [[Treaty|convention]] of [[linguistic rights]] that came into force on 1 March 1987, under the auspices of the [[Nordic Council]]. Under the Convention, citizens of the [[Nordic countries]] have the opportunity to use their [[native language]] when interacting with official bodies in other Nordic countries without being liable to any [[interpreting|interpretation]] or [[translation]] costs. The Convention covers health care, social security, tax, school, and employment authorities, the police and courts. The languages included are [[Swedish language|Swedish]], [[Danish language|Danish]], [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]], [[Finnish language|Finnish]] and [[Icelandic language|Icelandic]].<ref>[http://www.norden.org/en/about-nordic-co-operation/treaties-and-agreements/treaties-and-agreements/education-and-research/spraakkonventionen?set_language=en Konvention mellan Sverige, Danmark, Finland, Island och Norge om nordiska medborgares rätt att använda sitt eget språk i annat nordiskt land], ''Nordic Council website''. Retrieved on 25 April 2007.</ref><ref>[http://www.norden.org/en/news-and-events/news/20th-anniversary-of-the-nordic-language-convention/?searchterm=20th%20anniversary%20of%20the%20Nordic%20Language%20Convention 20th anniversary of the Nordic Language Convention], ''Nordic news'', 22 February 2007. Retrieved on 25 April 2007.</ref>
The Convention is not very well known and is mostly a recommendation. The countries have committed themselves to providing services in various languages, but citizens have no absolute rights except for criminal and court matters.<ref name=Wallin>[http://www.norden.org/en/news-and-events/news/language-convention-not-working-properly/?searchterm=Language%20Convention Language Convention not working properly], ''Nordic news'', 3 March 2007. Retrieved on 25 April 2007.</ref><ref name=Niska>Helge Niska, [http://www.fit-ift.org/cbi/download/sweden.pdf Community interpreting in Sweden: A short presentation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090327012606/http://www.fit-ift.org/cbi/download/sweden.pdf |date=2009-03-27 }}, [[International Federation of Translators]], 2004. Retrieved on 25 April 2007.</ref> The Convention does not automatically require authorities to provide services in another language but a citizen must demand an interpreter.<ref name=Niska/> Civil servants in official institutions are often unaware of the regulations on interpreting and translating and neglect to provide these services when requested.<ref name=Winsa> {{Citation |last1 = Winsa |first1 = Birger |title = Language Planning in Sweden |journal = Journal of Multilingual and Multicultural Development |volume = 20 |issue = 4 |pages = 376–473 |year = 1999 |url = http://www.multilingual-matters.net/jmmd/020/0376/jmmd0200376.pdf |id = |issn = 0143-4632 |accessdate = 2007-04-25 |doi = 10.1080/01434639908666384}}</ref> Furthermore, the convention excludes [[minority language]]s, like [[Faroese language|Faroese]], [[Kalaallisut language|Kalaallisut]], [[Romani language|Romany]] and [[Sami languages|Sami]], and [[immigrant language]]s.<ref name=Niska/><ref name=Winsa/> [[English language|English]] has also assumed an increasingly prominent role in interaction between Nordic citizens.<ref name=Wallin/>
==See also== *[[Nordic Council]] *[[Linguistic rights]]

In [[romantic literature]], a work has '''organic form''' if the structure has originated from the materials and subjects used by the author. Using the organic metaphor, the structure is seen to grow as a plant.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ajdrake.com/e491_fall_04/materials/guides/gd_rom_organic_metaphor.htm|title=The Organic Metaphor in Romantic Literature|last=Drake|first=Al|work=History of Literary Criticism – Guides|accessdate=7 November 2011}}</ref> It stands in contrast to a '''mechanical form''', a work which has been produced in accordance with artificial rules. The lack of rules in Shakespeare's works led some critics to claim that they lacked form; [[Samuel Taylor Coleridge]] leapt to his defence with the concept of organic form.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/431992/organic-form|title=Organic form|year=2011|work=Encyclopædia Britannica Online|publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica Inc.|accessdate=7 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.library.utoronto.ca/utel/glossary/Organic_form.html|title=Organic form|last1=Henderson|first1=Greig E.|last2=Brown|first2=Christopher|date=March 31, 1997|work=Glossary of Literary Theory|publisher=University of Toronto|accessdate=7 November 2011}}</ref>
==Overview== Coleridge, an English poet, philosopher, literary critic, and founder of the [[Romantic movement]], suggested that the concept of organic form meant that a poem or literary piece was shaped, rather than structured, from within. The use of the form allowed a piece to uniquely develop itself as it unfolded, and ultimately revealed an emphasis on the whole outcome of the piece, including the connections of each development to each other. In contrast to the more mechanical processes and rules which many critics believed were necessary for the formation of poetry and works, S.T. Coleridge determined that a more subconscious approach was possible through the, ‘‘imagination of the artist’’ whereby the outcome is an organic form, where ‘‘content and form have coalesced and fused.’’<ref>{{cite book|last=Bhatnagar|first=Manmohan K.|year=2000|publisher=Atlantic Publishers & Distributors|location=New Delhi|isbn=81-7156-631-6|pages=128|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0xRf3GleCQYC&dq=twentieth+century+literature+in+english+vol.2|title=Twentieth Century Literature in English}}</ref>
Coleridge's explanation can be found in Vol. 2 of [https://books.google.com/books?id=0xRf3GleCQYC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false ''Twentieth Century Literature in English''] :The form is mechanic when on any given material we impress a predetermined form, not necessarily arising out of the properties of the material-as when to a mass of wet clay we give whatever shape we wish it to retain when hardened. The organic form, on the other hand, is innate; it shapes as it develops itself from within, and the fullness of its development is one and the same with the perfection of its outward form.<ref>{{cite book|last=Bhatnagar|first=Manmohan K.|year=2000|publisher=Atlantic Publishers & Distributors|location=New Delhi|isbn=81-7156-631-6|pages=128|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0xRf3GleCQYC&dq=twentieth+century+literature+in+english+vol.2|title=Twentieth Century Literature in English}}</ref>
In R.A. Foake’s Introduction to [https://books.google.com/books?id=kRj3zH0Dck4C&printsec=frontcover&dq=Coleridge's+criticism+of+Shakespeare&hl=en&ei=apWRTe6hC9SPcNqLqIkH&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false "''Coleridge’s criticism of Shakespeare: a selection''"], he defines Coleridge’s defense of Shakespeare’s works as ‘’an act of sympathetic imagination, to enter into the spirit of each work, to reveal its inner organizing principle, and to show how Shakespeare, properly understood, was always in control and exercising judgement,’’<ref>{{cite book|last=Foakes|first=R. A.|year=1989|publisher=Athlone Press Ltd.|location=London|isbn=0-485-11349-X|pages=1–53|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kRj3zH0Dck4C&printsec=frontcover&dq=coleridge%27s+criticism+of+shakespeare:+a+selection+by+R.+A.+Foakes#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Coleridge's criticism of Shakespeare: A selection}}</ref>
Regarding Shakespeare’s much criticized erratic form, Coleridge further imposed the possibilities of organic form: :...each exterior is the [[physiognomy]] of the being within, its true image reflected and thrown out from the concave mirror; and even such is the appropriate excellence of her chosen poet, our own Shakespeare-himself a nature humanized, a genial understanding directing self-consciously a power and implicit wisdom deeper than consciousness.
Following on from Coleridge’s 18th Century ideas on organic form, was [[Gerard Manley Hopkins]], one of the most revered poets of the [[Victorian era]]<ref>{{cite web|title=From the Academy of American Poets|url=http://www.poets.org|accessdate=27 March 2011}}</ref> Hopkins introduced the terms “[[inscape]]” and “instress”. “Inscape” was the core components in individual objects, allowing him to then home in on its relation to other objects and their perception as a whole. “Instress” focussed on the assimilating the immediate apperception and the sensory processes of perception .<ref>{{cite journal|last=Levertov|first=Denise|title=Some Notes on Organic Form|journal=Poetry Foundation|date=September 1965|volume=106|issue=6|pages=420–425|jstor=40732772}}</ref>
20th-Century American poet [[Denise Levertov]] was an artist of organic form. In ‘Some notes on organic form’ she gives credit to Gerard Manley Hopkin’s influence on her own ideas and poetic form: :A partial definition, then, of organic poetry might be that it is a method of apperception, i.e., of recognizing what we perceive, and is based on an intuition of an order, a form beyond forms, in which forms partake, and of which man’s creative works are analogies, resemblances, natural allegories. Such poetry is exploratory.
Levertov believed that in order to achieve organic form in literature, the artist must be ‘brought to speech’ through a demanding sensory experience which renders them no choice but to put pen to paper.<ref name="www9.georgetown">{{cite web|last=Hallisey|first=Joan. F.|title=Denise Levertov (b. 1923)|url=http://www9.georgetown.edu/faculty/bassr/heath/syllabuild/iguide/levertov.html|publisher=Georgetown University|accessdate=March 27, 2011}}</ref> In her own work, Levertov concentrated on various techniques such as [[enjambment]], popular with much of Shakespeare’s work, and ‘juxtaposition of key words’ for effect. Avenues were carefully sought and deliberated upon to create the ‘right words, the right image, the right arrangement of the lines on the page’.<ref name="www9.georgetown"/> Many artists of organic form believed that a reader or audience were not immediately, if ever, considered during the construction of a poem or piece. Levertov, included, felt it was essential that a poem be produced from the ‘inner being of the poet’.<ref name="www9.georgetown" />
Organic form in literature was also theorized by Schelling.<ref>{{cite book|last=Matthews|first=Bruce|year=2011|publisher=State University Of New York|location=Albany|title=Schelling’s Organic Form of Philosophy: Life as the Schema of Freedom}}</ref> Bruce Matthews suggests that, insofar as Schelling understands life according to a schema of freedom of thinking, representations are not absolutely different, and subjects and objects are grounded in an identity that links them together. Matthews argues that Schelling’s organic philosophy strives to support an integrated framework where conceptual ideas are scrutinized, challenging ideas and concepts in hopes to create a more significant understanding of the world.

Foakes''] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=0xRf3GleCQYC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false ''Twentieth Century Literature in English''] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=fKkBO8EAE6oC&pg=PA81&dq=studies+in+romanticism+daniel+stempel&hl=en&ei=AZqRTczfMo2ecfrUvIkH&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=organic%20form&f=false ''Romanticism and the uses of genre'']
[[Category:Literary concepts]]

The '''overshooting model''', or the '''exchange rate overshooting hypothesis''', first developed by economist [[Rudi Dornbusch]], is a theoretical explanation for high levels of [[exchange rate]] volatility. The key features of the model include the assumptions that goods' prices are sticky, or slow to change, in the short run, but the prices of currencies are flexible, that [[arbitrage]] in asset markets holds, via the [[uncovered interest parity]] equation, and that expectations of exchange rate changes are "consistent": that is, [[rational expectations|rational]]. The most important insight of the model is that adjustment lags in some parts of the economy can induce compensating volatility in others; specifically, when an [[exogenous]] variable changes, the short-term effect on the exchange rate can be greater than the long-run effect, so in the short term, the exchange rate ''overshoots'' its new equilibrium long-term value.
Dornbusch developed this model back when many economists held the view that ideal markets should reach equilibrium and stay there. Volatility in a market, from this perspective, could only be a consequence of imperfect or [[information asymmetry|asymmetric information]] or adjustment obstacles in that market. Rejecting this view, Dornbusch argued that volatility is in fact a far more fundamental property than that.
According to the model, when a change in monetary policy occurs (e.g., an unanticipated permanent increase in the money supply), the market will adjust to a new equilibrium between prices and quantities. Initially, because of the "stickiness" of prices of goods, the new short run equilibrium level will first be achieved through shifts in financial market prices. Then, gradually, as prices of goods "unstick" and shift to the new equilibrium, the [[foreign exchange market]] continuously reprices, approaching its new long-term equilibrium level. Only after this process has run its course will a new long-run equilibrium be attained in the domestic money market, the currency exchange market, and the goods market.
As a result, the foreign exchange market will initially overreact to a monetary change, achieving a new short run equilibrium. Over time, goods prices will eventually respond, allowing the foreign exchange market to dissipate its overreaction, and the economy to reach the new long run equilibrium in all markets.
== Outline of the model ==
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Assumption 1: | Aggregate demand is determined by the standard open economy [[IS-LM]] mechanism |} That is to say, the position of the Investment Saving (IS) curve is determined by the volume of injections into the flow of income and by the competitiveness of Home country output measured by the real exchange rate.
The first assumption is essentially saying that the IS curve (demand for goods) position is in some way dependent on the real [[effective exchange rate]] Q.
That is, [IS = C + I + G +Nx(Q)]. In this case, net exports is dependent on Q (as Q goes up, foreign countries' goods are relatively more expensive, and home countries' goods are cheaper, therefore there are higher net exports).
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Assumption 2: | Financial Markets are able to adjust to shocks instantaneously, and investors are risk neutral. |} If financial markets can adjust instantaneously and investors are risk neutral, it can be said the uncovered [[interest rate parity]] (UIP) holds at all times. That is, the equation r = r* + Δs<sup>e</sup> holds at all times (explanation of this formula is below).
It is clear, then, that an expected depreciation/appreciation offsets any current difference in the exchange rate. If r > r*, the exchange rate (domestic price of one unit of foreign currency) is expected to increase. That is, the domestic currency depreciates relative to the foreign currency.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Assumption 3: | In the short run, goods prices are 'sticky'. That is, aggregate supply is horizontal in the short run, though it is positively sloped in the long run. |} In the long run, the exchange rate(s) will equal the long run equilibrium exchange rate,(ŝ).
{| class="wikitable" |- |r: the domestic interest rate |r*: the foreign interest rate |s: exchange rate |- |Δs<sup>e</sup>: expected change in exchange rate |θ: coefficient reflecting the sensitivity of a market participant to the (proportionate) overvaluation/undervaluation of the currency relative to equilibrium. |ŝ: long-run expected exchange rate |- |m: money supply/demand |p: price index |k: constant term |- |l: constant term |y<sup>d</sup>: demand for domestic output |h: constant |- |q: real exchange rate |þ: change in prices with respect to time |π: prices |- |ŷ: long-run demand for domestic output (constant) |p_hat: Long run equilibrium price level |} '''Formal Notation'''
[1] r = r* +Δse (uncovered interest rate parity - approximation)
[2] Δs<sup>e</sup> = θ(ŝ – s) (Expectations of market participants)
[3] m - p = ky-lr (Demand/Supply on money)
[4] y<sup>d</sup> = h(s-p) = h(q) (demand for the home country output)
[5] þ = π(yd- ŷ)(proportional change in prices with respect to time) dP/dTime
From the above can be derived the following (using algebraic substitution)
[6] p - p_hat = - lθ(ŝ - s)
[7] þ = π[h(s-p) - ŷ]
'''In equilibrium'''
y<sup>d</sup> = ŷ (demand for output equals the long run demand for output)
from this substitution shows that [8] ŷ/h = ŝ - p_hat That is, in the long run, the only variable that affects the real exchange rate is growth in capacity output.
Also, Δs<sup>e</sup> = 0 (that is, in the long run the expected change of inflection is equal to zero)
Substituting into [2] yields r = r*. Substituting that into [6] shows:
[9] p_hat = m -kŷ + l r*
taking [8] & [9] together:
[10] ŝ = ŷ(h<sup>−1</sup> - k) + m +lr*
comparing [9] & [10], it is clear that the only difference between them is the intercept (that is the slope of both is the same). This reveals that given a rise in money stock pushes up the long run values of both in equally proportional measures, the real exchange rate (q) must remain at the same value as it was before the market shock. Therefore, the properties of the model at the beginning are preserved in long run equilibrium, the original equilibrium was stable.
'''Short run disequilibrium'''
The standard approach is to rewrite the basic equations [6] & [7] in terms of the deviation from the long run equilibrium). In equilibrium [7] implies 0 = π[h(ŝ-p_hat) - ŷ] Subtracting this from [7] yields
[11] þ = π[h(q-q_hat) The rate of exchange is positive whenever the real exchange rate is above its equilibrium level, also it is moving towards the equilibrium level] - This yields the direction and movement of the exchange rate.
In equilibrium, [9] hold, that is [6] - [9] is the difference from equilibrium. →←← [12] p - p_hat = -lθ(s-ŝ) This shows the line upon which the exchange rate must be moving (the line with slope -lθ).
Both [11] & [12] together demonstrates that the exchange rate will be moving towards the long run equilibrium exchange rate, whilst being in a position that implies that it was initially overshot. From the assumptions above, it is possible to derive the following situation. This demonstrated the overshooting and subsequent readjustment. In the graph on the top left, So is the initial long run equilibrium, S1 is the long run equilibrium after the injection of extra money and S2 is where the exchange rate initially jumps to (thus overshooting). When this overshoot takes place, it begins to move back to the new long run equilibrium S1.

page.title: Persecution of Jews and Muslims by Manuel I of Portugal

revision.comment: /* Crypto-Jews */ Rabbi per se doesn't get capitalized, just like priest or minister.
revision.text:
{{see also|history of the Jews in Portugal}}
[[Image:Manuel - Epistola de victoria contra infideles habita, 1507 - 4592250.tif|thumb|''Epistola de victoria contra infideles habita'', 1507]]
On 5 December 1496, [[Manuel I of Portugal|King Manuel I of Portugal]] signed the decree of expulsion of Jews and Muslims to take effect by the end of October of the next year.<ref name=Decree>António José Saraiva: The Marrano Factory: The Portuguese Inquisition and Its New Christians 1536-1765, BRILL, 2001, {{ISBN|9789004120808}}, p. 10-12.</ref>
== Background == Until the 15th century, some Jews occupied prominent places in Portuguese political and economic life. For example, [[Isaac Abrabanel]] was the treasurer of King [[Afonso V of Portugal]]. Many also had an active role in [[Portuguese culture]], and they kept their reputation of diplomats and merchants. By this time, [[Lisbon]] and [[Évora]] were home to important Jewish communities.
== Expulsion of Jews== [[File:A Expulsão dos Judeus (Roque Gameiro, Quadros da História de Portugal, 1917).png|250px|thumb|Expulsion of the Jews in 1497, in a 1917 watercolour by [[Alfredo Roque Gameiro]]]] On 5 December 1496, because a clause of the contract of marriage between himself and [[Isabella, Princess of Asturias (1470–1498)|Isabella, Princess of Asturias]] stipulated he do so in order to win her hand, King [[Manuel I of Portugal]] decreed that all Jews must convert to [[Catholicism]] or leave the country. One set of laws demonstrated the King's wish to completely and forever eradicate Judaism from Portugal.<ref name=Decree/> The initial edict of expulsion was turned into an edict of forced conversion in 1497: Portuguese Jews were prevented from leaving the country and forcibly converted to Christianity. Hard times followed for the Portuguese conversos, with [[Lisbon Massacre|the massacre of 2,000 individuals in Lisbon in 1506]] and the later and even more relevant establishment of the [[Portuguese Inquisition]] in 1536.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sao Tome & Principle|url=http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/vjw/saotome_principe.html|website=Jewish Virtual Library}}</ref> The Portuguese inquisition was extinguished in 1821 by the "General Extraordinary and Constituent [[Portuguese Cortes|Courts of the Portuguese Nation]]".
When the King allowed conversos to leave after the Lisbon massacre of 1506, many went to the Ottoman Empire (notably [[Thessaloniki]] and [[Constantinople]] and to [[Wattasid Dynasty|Morocco]]. Smaller numbers went to [[Amsterdam]], [[Kingdom of France|France]], [[Colony of Brazil|Brazil]], [[Curaçao]] and the [[Antilles]]. In some of these places their presence can still be witnessed, like the use of the [[Judeo-Spanish|Ladino]] language by some Jewish communities in [[Turkey]], the [[Papiamento|Portuguese based dialects]] of the Antilles, or the multiple [[synagogue]]s built by those who became known as the [[Spanish and Portuguese Jews]], such as the [[Amsterdam Esnoga]].
Jews who converted to Christianity were known as [[New Christians]], and were always under the constant surveillance of the Inquisition. Many of those were [[crypto-Jew]]s who continued to secretly practice their religion; they eventually left the country in the centuries to come and again embraced openly their Jewish faith. Such was the case, for example, of the family of Baruch Spinoza.
[[File:Inquis1.jpg|thumb|250px|Burning of Crypto-Jews in Lisbon, Portugal]] Some of the most famous descendants of Portuguese Jews who lived outside Portugal are the philosopher [[Baruch Spinoza]] (from Portuguese Bento de Espinosa), and the classical economist [[David Ricardo]].
=== Crypto-Jews ===
Some Jews, very few, like the [[Belmonte Jews]], went for a different and radical solution, practicing their faith in a strict secret isolated community. Known as the [[Marranos]], some have survived until today (basically only the community from Belmonte, plus some more isolated families) by the practice of inmarriage and few cultural contacts with the outside world. Only recently have they re-established contact with the international Jewish community and openly practice their religion in a public synagogue with a formal [[rabbi]].
==Expulsion of Muslims== According to contemporary historian François Soyer, the expulsion of Muslims from Portugal has been overshadowed by the forced conversion of Jews in the country.{{sfn|Soyer|2007|p=241}} While tolerance of Muslim minorities in Portugal was higher than in any other part of Europe,{{sfn|Soyer|2007|p=258}} Muslims were still perceived as "alien."{{sfn|Soyer|2007|p=254, 259}} Anti-Muslim riots were regular in neighboring [[Kingdom of Valencia|Valencia]] during the 1460s; however, no similar acts of violence occurred in Portugal.{{sfn|Soyer|2007|p=258}}
In December 1496, Manuel I ordered all Muslim subjects to leave without any apparent provocation.{{sfn|Soyer|2007|p=242}} According to 15th-century Portuguese historians [[Damião de Góis]] and [[Jerónimo Osório]], the Portuguese government originally planned to forcibly convert or execute Muslims as they had done to Jews, but fear of retaliation from Muslim kingdoms in North Africa led the king to settle on deportations instead.{{sfn|Soyer|2007|pp=260-261}} Manuel I's motivation behind the order is unclear, but some contemporary historians say it was part of a greater goal of Queen [[Isabella I of Castile|Isabella]] and King [[Ferdinand II of Aragon|Ferdinand]] (known as the "[[Catholic Monarchs]]") to rid the peninsula of Muslims and create "religious uniformity" and "monolithic Catholic Christian unity".{{sfn|Soyer|2007|p=269}} Other historians say it was influenced by ambitions of conquering Morocco,{{sfn|Soyer|2007|p=280}} or by the suggestion of the Dominican confessor to the king, Friar Jorge Vogado.{{sfn|Soyer|2007|p=273}} Some Muslims found refuge in [[Crown of Castile|Castile]],{{sfn|Soyer|2007|p=262}} but most fled to North Africa.{{sfn|Soyer|2007|p=268}}
== Return of some Jews to Portugal ==
In the 19th century, some affluent families of Sephardi Jewish Portuguese origin such as the Ruah and Bensaude, resettled in Portugal from Morocco. The first synagogue to be built in Portugal since the 15th century was the [[Lisbon Synagogue]], inaugurated in 1904.
In 2014 the Portuguese parliament changed the [[Portuguese nationality law]] in order to grant Portuguese nationality to descendants of [[Sephardi Jews]] expelled from Portugal. The law is a reaction to historical events that led to their expulsion from Portugal, but also due to increased concerns over Jewish communities throughout Europe. In order to obtain Portuguese nationality, the person must have a family surname that attests to being a direct descendant of a Sephardi of Portuguese origin or family connections in a collateral line from a former Portuguese Sephardi community. Use of expressions in Portuguese in Jewish rites or [[Judaeo-Portuguese]] or [[Judaeo-Spanish|Ladino]] can also be considered proof.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.publico.pt/politica/noticia/descendentes-de-judeus-sefarditas-ja-vao-poder-pedir-a-nacionalidade-1684394|title=Descendentes de judeus sefarditas já vão poder pedir a nacionalidade|author=Lusa|work=PÚBLICO}}</ref>
From 2015 several hundred [[Turkish Jews]] who were able to prove descent from [[Portuguese Jews]] expelled in 1497 [[immigration to Portugal|emigrated to Portugal]] and acquired [[Portuguese nationality law#Jewish Law of Return|Portuguese citizenship]].<ref>http://www.timesofisrael.com/amid-rising-european-anti-semitism-portugal-sees-jewish-renaissance/</ref><ref>http://www.timesofisrael.com/new-citizenship-law-has-jews-flocking-to-tiny-portugal-city/</ref><ref>http://www.jta.org/2015/03/03/news-opinion/world/portugal-open-to-citizenship-applications-by-descendants-of-sephardic-jews</ref>
